segments.Text: Isn't that going considering that...
Okay, how many of you here have ever tried to drive in Los Angeles?
Okay, yeah.
Yeah, well, you know, I'm not.
Okay, so yeah, we get people there.
Our meeting's a little unusual.
We actually meet in three different locations.
We start off at Union Station.
station, right in the middle of downtown. We're there from 5 to 7, which is the official
2,600 meeting time. After that, we moved to Philippe's Deli, which is about a block away.
We're there till 10 when they closed, but people don't start turning up till 8, which means
that at 10 p.m., we move over to the Denny's by the scenic city jail, which is a great
place to be hanging out at midnight when they start releasing folks, and it gets real interesting.
But generally, even though we're running that late, we still get a large number of people.
yeah, we're getting 45, 50 people a month turning up.
The problem is, we had one month where we actually had a grand total of eight people turn up.
We said, screw this, and went off and saw a movie.
We needed to save it.
Pretty much the problem was in Southern California, and a lot of other people were saying this as well,
the scene was dying.
They had no point of contact, no point of entry to actually talk to people about things they were interested in.
So we started working on reviving it.
The main thing that brought it back was we started printing flyers and updating the website regularly.
And that's kind of brought people in.
I know you guys were in pretty much the same boat.
Yeah.
We had, I'll give you some background on Salt Lake.
Salt Lake 2,600 meeting started, and I think it was 1996 with about two people going to a coffee shop every month, religiously, who were friends.
But there was no advertising, there was no webpage or anything like that, nothing in 2,600 to say.
there. It was just kind of like we're at a 2600 meeting. I moved from New York to Salt Lake City
and was not aware that there was any, you know, scene in Salt Lake. Actually, there are a slogan for
2600 Salt Lake City is, believe it or not, there are in Utah, because everybody who shows up to
the meeting thought they were the only one in Utah, and now we get in attendance about between, I think it's
like 35 to 40 people.
which isn't bad considering, I'm going to badge on here for a second.
Utah has two million people in it.
L.A. has about, what, 8 million?
8 million people in it.
So we're almost at L.A., so.
Yeah.
I mean, geez, the simple fact you were able to bring that many people out of the woodwork, I mean,
by numbers alone, we should, you know, if this is taken as a ratio,
we should probably have about 160 people turning up every month.
Is this?
Yeah, something is this way.
It's the metal badges.
I blame you.
But when I started going to the meetings, it was about two and a half to three years ago.
There were seven people there or so.
The first person I met was Almas in the EOC, who's hawking T-shirts in the vendor area right now.
We, from the first time I went, I talked to one of the founders, Kenny of Hectic.
And said, hey, I saw your page.
It was like a one-page thing that said, this is where the meeting is,
and this is where, what times we meet, blah, blah, blah,
same deal as, you know, default 2600 meeting times.
And I said, I'd like to do something with a little more content,
maybe get some pictures up there, contact information for people who come to the meeting.
I don't know how many people here attend 2,600 regularly or at all.
All right.
Well, if you go to a 2600 meeting and you're,
meet somebody and you're like, you can meet 30 people, and then there's one person that
you really connect with on something, or there's a project you'd like to work on together,
and then you forget their handle, you know, a super ultra-nid ninja killer or something like that,
and you're like, I can't remember that to his handle, and, but you'd like to get in contact with me.
So when I would go to the meetings, anybody who was new, I'd take down their, you know, their
handle, email address, website, and, you know, put it on the page.
We don't do that anymore, because if you can't remember.
remember I'm just tired of collecting email addresses, but when we first started out, it was good
because it got people back together. If someone fell out of the meeting for a month, then they'd
get an email from the person who was like, hey, you know, you were talking about that project,
and I really want to talk about it. Oh, okay, I'll be at the next meeting. And so people just started
coming together. I started printing up flyers, putting them in the issues of $2,600 at, you know,
Barnes & Noble borders, dropping them in technical schools and the CS departments of,
local colleges and whatnot. And we started getting attendance. People were coming a lot more,
but we were starting to attract a lot of the script kitty slash scene whore group. Now, our attendance
was up, and that was great, and we thought, hey, look at us. We have, you know, these big numbers,
but the percentage that was actually there to talk about things that were technical or even
talk about anything constructive at all, it was probably about half. Like,
everyone would go off into little groups and talk about things, and there was the, you know, the guys who would run around and try to, you know.
Hey, hey, dude, hell, I got this, I get this, I got, right? I'm talking about here.
And, so it got to the point where we had all these people, and there was someone who showed up the meeting one time.
A guy never contributed, anything like that. He shows up. He leaves the food court. We have it in a food court, a pretty large one.
And we're back in the corner, so we don't bother anybody. But he shows up and says, like, and he goes off onto, onto,
out into the mall, and he comes back with a couple cell phones. And apparently he'd stolen the cell phones
from the kiosks out there, and he decided it wouldn't be a good idea to come back to the
2,600 meeting, and take these apart. And he starts ripping him apart, and, you know,
he's like 16, 17 years old, and at the time I'm, like, 21, and I'm like, you're an idiot. I'm the one
who's going to get in trouble for this, not you, you know? They'll just slap you and throw you out of
the mall. But I brought you here. So, I was fed up at that point with,
with that kind of attitude there at the meeting. And I talked to some of the founders and I said,
I'm going to lay the smack down. I'm just going to say, look, here's how it's going to be. We're
going to have structure. For the first hour, talk about whatever you want. Talk about movies.
Oh, do you see Minority Report? Did you see, you know, whatever? And then starting at 6 o'clock,
we have talks. I get on everybody, all the, some of the Salt Lake guys are here in the front row.
They will attest to the fact that I will get on their case.
about, dude, write a talk, come on, you've got to write something. You haven't written anything
in almost a year. And at 6 o'clock, they start giving their talks. And when those are over,
the conversation starts again. But since we had those talks, it lends to more technical discussions.
And I basically have said, if you don't want to listen to the talks, it's a big food court,
go over there and talk over there. But do not talk while someone else is talking. I mean,
you know, honestly, let's be mature and have some manners. It takes a lot to put together
a talk and then even more to get up in front of a group of people and present it.
So have respect for the people who are there, if you don't like it, go away.
But that became, it kind of became self-policing.
The technical-minded people have taken over the meeting again.
I did a talk that was, the first talk ever was last April,
and it was called Script Kitties and Seenhoras.
not to be one and why we hate them. And it was based off of, I mean, good point.
You know, it's, it actually, the talk is mirrored on 2600slc.org, which is our meeting site.
All of the talks that are given at the meeting are on that site under texts.
But, so I presented this thing, and it was based off of Pyro and Shattered did a talk called
FACT the Kitties at DefCon 8, where they basically laid it down and said, this is how you should
behave and you don't have anything to prove, don't, if, you know,
know, let people think you're an idiot, don't open your mouth and prove it.
Yeah, I mean, people have this strange idea that the minute you send them to a 2,600 meeting,
it's a license to behave like a complete and utter tit.
They're, the mind boggles. I don't understand this.
It's like, you know, the normal bounds of society suddenly don't apply.
And then they look really shocked when there's all these angry people turning on them going,
what the hell are you doing?
You know, you are not wanted here because of your behavior.
They don't seem to get this.
And it's,
it's very much a double-edged sword.
You turn up, you act like a dick, people aren't going to want you there.
They don't understand this.
Yeah.
One of the things is, like, if we don't want you there, if you're not there,
like, if you can come and not contribute, and that's fine, if you're, if you're learning or you're
interested in learning, but if you're sitting there and stealing things from inside the mall
and going and breaking that apart of our meeting, then, you know, I have no patience for
unintelligent people.
So it's like, we laid it down.
Some people were kind of, if,
be on it at first, they're like, oh, I don't know about this.
You know, I like just going and being social with people and whatnot, but after about six months
when they saw the decline in, you know, the morons, basically, and that the discussions that we had
were becoming more tech-related or, you know, just learning from each other and being able to
say, I don't know, is huge when you go to anything.
I don't know is okay.
Hey, I don't know if anybody knows that, but we have a guy who's really good at that.
Like everyone, it'll be like, does everybody know what the network OSI model is,
and everyone will sit there and go, yes, yes, I do, and they really don't.
And then someone will go, no, I have no idea.
And it's like, cool.
And you explain it really quick, and now everyone else can understand because one guy had enough balls to say, I don't know.
So, I don't know.
I was just going to say, you know, asking questions, you're not taking questions, you're not
painting yourself is appearing ignorant.
Everybody doesn't know everything.
I certainly don't.
Grifter doesn't.
Nobody else does.
Speak for yourself, dude.
You know, we won't get into what happened with the radio's yesterday.
But, you know, I mean, you know, if you don't ask questions, you're not going to learn anything.
And you're not going to get anything out of it.
And if you're not encouraging people to ask questions, the meetings are going to go to hell.
You know, you're going to have a bunch of people sitting around drinking coffee and talking about the DVD
they went in a blockbook.
for last night.
Yeah, agreed.
Basically, where the resurrecting the scene, how many people even believe that there still is a scene
that is attached to this?
Are there?
A few stragglers?
Hangers on.
These are the people who will carry this into the future, the ones who don't think it's dead
or it's not impossible to bring back.
It's, yes, you know, hackers came out in 1995, and the scene took quite a shot in the
guy, well, that, that, and the fact that anybody with 500 bucks to spare can walk down
to Comp USA, buy a cheap computer, plug it into their phone line, and they're now online.
And that was the real thing that started bringing about the demise of everything, because,
let's face it, the internet is pretty much the full scope of what most people focus on in terms
of hacking.
And hacking, to me, is not purely about the internet.
It's about finding ways of doing things that were previously thought not possible.
By giving people basically cheap all-you-can-eat-access, that's what the focus became.
How many people do you still think are playing with the phone system, for example?
I mean, there's some pretty, there are some people out there doing it, but it's really bubbled under everything
because the focus has shifted, and the focus has become very narrow.
One good thing about the meetings is you actually get a chance to bring the people in who are interested
in all these different aspects of hacking and get them together and talk.
And actually show that there is a focus out there.
And a sharing of ideas and of ideals.
What I, where it comes in with resurrecting the scene, where I want to move our 2600 meeting to,
like we've taken the steps to have the structure and to start doing the talks and they're mirrored on the website,
and we have, you know, the news section that's updated and photos from the meeting.
You can go to the Salt Lake City website and actually, like, know what went on there
because everything is there.
The talks are there. You can see who is there.
You can read about what happened.
Yeah, I was going to say, conversely, you know, Salt Lake has a pretty good structure to how everything works
in terms of the flow of the time of the meeting.
We don't really tend to do that.
What generally happens is on the mailing list, people start throwing out ideas talking about it,
turn up at the meeting, and it's like, okay, everybody who was interested in the wireless stuff
we were talking on the list, go over here.
And they'll take over a corner of the meeting.
And, you know, people are wondering and out, but you'll have a core group of people who are actually interested in what's going on,
and everybody else is off doing their own thing, which also works for us.
I mean, it's all in the context of how the meeting's being set up and run.
I think the, as far as our meetings go, where we're going with this, do people still read 2,600 anymore?
Can I get a show of hands who reads 2,600?
All right, so there are people out there.
Whenever I say, oh, like, for instance, on FN,
I joined Pound 2,600 and say, because I heard that, oh, one of the talks I gave it 2600 was published,
I said, does anyone have the new issue of 2,600?
Now, this is in Pound 2,600.
Oh, man, oh, that's a bunch of crap, you still read that, oh, you kiddie, blah, blah, blah.
I'm like, what the hell?
This is also on IRc.2600.net, I should point out.
So, yeah.
Yeah, which is dead now.
Let's go out and down for a while, but yeah.
But I think where people need to take it is getting that back to where it used to be.
A lot of people say it's a political rag.
Some people say, well, that's good.
I like the fact that it's a political rag because I can find out all the politics that I need to find out about
that involve technology through 2,600.
And, like, I'm not going to sit here and bash 2,600 all day, but, yeah, I think it's a little too political.
I don't read the editor's comments anymore.
I read the articles, the ones that are good.
And one of the things that the LA meeting specifically has been trying to do is sort of divorce itself from all of the more political bullshit that's going on in the magazine.
You know, we very much understand what the magazine is meant to be about, what it's meant to represent.
And I can't speak for everybody necessarily, but I can say that personally, I do feel that it's moving away from its technical focus.
And so what we try to do is very much keep ourselves neutral on that and basically keep the politics out of hacking.
Politics is something that's personal.
It doesn't have a... Put it this way. I don't spend my five bucks on the magazine because I want a consciousness raising session.
I want source code. And that's really what it comes down to.
Well, that's a good point.
Actually, would you mind saying it a bit louder for the benefit of the cameras?
That's a good point. And there are definitely things such as the DMCA that cross both boundaries that are both political and hacking related.
And I'm certainly, I'm certainly not going to deny that.
However, I don't feel that hacking should be about politics.
I feel that it should be about hacking and improving things.
How the improvements are done, that's another question.
Having an article...
Oh, sorry, I was just going to say it's a very wide-ranging debate. I'd be happy to talk about it with you afterwards.
We just...
Yeah, you can go for hours now.
There's a difference between having an article about the EFF or having an article about the DMCA
versus having a magazine with four to five to six articles about...
the DMCA, four to five to six articles about the EFF, things like that. You know,
EFF's a great organization. I just don't want to read a book about it every quarter.
But everybody complains about it, but nobody does anything about it. So that's where,
like, the talk that I did got published, it's on dumpster diving, and I said, hey, you know,
what the hell? I'll take this one, I'll submit it, and I'll see if they publish it. And I'd like to see,
our text area of our website that says, you know, like I have a list of all the different talks
that have been given over the last year, and I'd like to see things like, you know,
published in the winter 2003 or, you know, published in spring of 2003 next to it,
taking these technical talks and getting them out there for everyone to see.
Well, actually, you're making another good point here peripherally.
You know, the things you cover don't have to be ultra-high-level, you know, uber-technical things.
You know, not everybody needs to have source code thrown at them.
There are a lot of things out there, like dumpster diving, that people still, you know, you can't go,
I've had people say to me, oh, you can't go dumpster diving.
Like, you know, dumpster diving is a logical impossibility.
Okay, now let me see.
Okay, dumpster, open, trash.
Climbing, grab stuff, go away.
You know, you can do it.
And people don't seem to realize that a lot of what relates to hacking is really basic stuff like that.
And there's a lot of people who need to know about it, because if they don't hear about it, they're never going to go any further.
It's going to give them the push to start looking into things a little bit more than they are already.
Sorry, you have a question?
I'm sorry, I can't hear you.
Who is this 2600 magazine that one of the largest groups is trying to divorce themselves from it?
Who's putting out the magazine of this?
Well, okay.
Okay, the magazine and the meetings are two separate beasts.
The magazine, the gap the meetings, basically.
They started in New York City, about what, 86, 7, possibly a little sooner, I'm not sure.
But, you know, the idea of the meetings then spread.
I guess what it comes down to is a case of the views of the management do not necessarily
represent those of its employees.
The other thing you have to remember two is 2,600 isn't a group.
is a magazine. And even though, you know, we're having our meetings under the 2,600 name,
we're no more a part of them than we are the Shriners. So, should give you some idea on that.
Doing things like, like you said, like sharing the culture with people, things like that,
I'd like to see people take what others have out there. Update your websites. If you're planning
to have a meeting, that's critical. If people don't see that you.
or websites being updated on a regular basis, they won't come because if it says last updated,
what was that, 1996?
Yeah, while back I was going through, I was actually hitting up every single meeting home page
that 2,600 had listed on their site.
I just wanted to see what other people were up to.
You know, I was just curious like, okay, you know, how does the meeting in Topeka get along,
you know, and poking around?
And, yeah, we found one that was still listed as active, and they hadn't updated the website in, you know,
six years.
which is a little frightening because, well, if you've got anybody who wants to turn up to it,
they're going to look at it and go, yeah, right, okay.
Yeah, it's probably dead, or the people who ran it aren't even there anymore.
Yeah.
I'd like to see that happen, like, see people starting to do things where you can go
and find out what they did and what they talked on and have it there
and be able to, if I don't feel like writing something every month,
it would be nice to be.
able to go to, you know, the New York City or the L.A. 2,600, and pull one of their talks
off of their website and say, the guys from L.A. did this. This is what we're going to talk
about. Maybe somebody who's sitting there listening to that will get something else. Then
they'll go to the website, grab it, make some changes, submit it back to the author of the original
talk, and it just gets better and better from there. Things just improve.
The idea has become better and people get smarter is basically what it comes down to.
As a group, as a whole, we're a lot more intelligent than we are standing alone.
Yeah, I mean, this is also something that's very important.
You need to get in touch with the other groups, not just in your area, but on a wider basis.
You know, for some reason, actually, can I have that, please?
I'm real thirsty.
Thanks.
One second.
We'll both.
Yeah.
Yeah, this is one thing that's important is to go to other meetings that are being held that you know about.
Reason being, you know, it's a good idea to see what other people are up to, but it also helps
to reestablish the community by doing that. I've been to do a lot of 2,600 meetings in different
cities, both inside and outside, all right, I'm going to die here, both inside and outside the U.S.
And really establishing that contact and keeping it firm is pretty essential.
Without it, you know, there won't be an underground.
You have to have people in contact with each other who can exchange ideas.
I have to.
All right.
I totally agree with what he's saying.
Getting out there, like, I don't have the time, sorry.
But we have had people come visit our meetings and come from other places around the country,
and they're like, wow, you know, you guys really have your act together.
You're doing something here.
You know, that's great.
Oh, I wish my 2,600 meeting was like this.
And, you know, my simple question.
question is, why isn't it? It doesn't take much because, you know, for the sake of making
myself sound like an idiot, if I can do it, anybody can. So, I mean.
Yeah, I mean, essentially a stable meeting location, a website that gets updated regularly,
and a mailing list. Those are the three main things you're going to need to actually set it up
and keep everybody together and things going.
Or an IRC channel. Yeah. Or two.
Four. Yeah.
Does anybody have any experiences they want to share as far as their meetings, how their meetings are structured and whatnot?
I'm from Oklahoma and the city. What we tried recently is kind of dividing, like you said, is a good idea.
My first start showing up, we were just kidding around the ball.
It was just a smaller coffee shop where they got out with your pool.
It was like to see you. We had to the wall to project on.
And then we said, you know, we all have a private-to-do, you know, a half an hour,
bring your conversation, half an hour, hacker, computer conversation.
power on political conversations.
See, that's pretty cool because the guys, I've been saying, and that's pretty cool because
the guys, I think you're saying, this white guys, and the greener guys can start pulling out
on this equipment, really frost there is, and it's been working out really well.
See, that's great. I mean, perfect example. You just go and you, if you're just hanging out
in a food court, that's what you're doing. You're not having a $2,600 meeting. You're hanging
out in the food court. You know, that's, what's the difference there?
Yeah, I mean, if you actually equally lame.
Yeah. I mean, that's, that's the, you're just, you're just, you know, I mean, that's the

other thing too. You need to do two things with your location. You need to pick it well. You've got to have somewhere stable because I know you guys are meeting in a food court. Pretty much, we can't do that. There's no mall in downtown L.A. And, you know, trying to find a meeting place in Los Angeles is great because, well, just the acreage of the place, it's massive. So we pick somewhere mutually inconvenient to everybody, which is downtown. But pretty much, you know, you meet in a coffee shop. You can make yourselves noticeable because you're in a smaller setting. You stand out.
a little bit more. The other thing, too, is you've got to keep good relations with where you're meeting.
If you burn your hosts, you know, ultimately, you don't own the meeting location.
They're just going to kick you out and tell you never to come back, and that's their prerogative.
You've got people stealing things, breaking things, running around molesting the other customers,
you know, swinging dead cats over their heads and chanting yabah, yabba, yabba.
They're not surprised how often that happened. Yeah.
Seriously. We won't get into that.
No, seriously, you know, if they don't like you, they're just going to kick you out, and no one meeting's screwed then.
Yeah. Definitely being on good terms. We didn't ask to use the food court. We just kind of happened upon it.
And like I said, when it was there, there were like seven people. They didn't care. And now that there's like 40, they started to notice.
And they, like, the security guards would come by and they were like, oh, you're having your computer meetings again.
And they haven't, yeah, I saw you guys here last week.
we're like, all right.
They still haven't figured out it's the first Friday of every month.
No.
So maybe we're just still there because they don't know when to catch us.
Actually, there was a question there.
Does we have to be on that Friday, can we be enough to give the week?
It's really hard when the place that you may be here today
or the people that were possible to use to their net are into miniature gaming and to other.
Sure.
Sure.
You got a lot of competition for Friday's period.
Well, let me give you an example on that.
We're using the first Friday analogy simply because that's when 2,600 meetings are supposed to happen.
No, but I heard that we were supposed to, okay, it doesn't have to be the answer.
No, I mean, you can do it anytime.
I mean, to give you some example, we've got a BBS meet that a bunch of us go to every Tuesday night.
And, you know, we turn up in the pizza place, we eat pizza, try not to leave too much
of a mess. But it's actually interesting you mentioned the role playing people because, yeah,
back in the other corner away from us, we've got another group that they're role playing people.
They meet there the same night we do. So it's entirely a possibility. I mean, you know, you can't
say like what day you're going to have your meeting on. You just do it when it's most convenient
for everybody involved.
And again, we're talking about 2,600 meetings because we both run them, but it doesn't have
to be a 2,600 meeting. You can say, you know, it's the whatever meeting and have it on any day
you want it's not a necessity. Although I do recommend consistently using either the same day
of the month or like, you know, $2,600 is the first Friday, doing something like that so that
that people, you know, know to show up that time.
Yeah.
I'm sorry, I couldn't hear you.
Yeah, or it's like, you know, people call the pay phones at BLA meet occasionally. And it's like, you know, last month, this guy,
calls up, he's like, you know, is that the 2,600 meeting? I'm like, no, sorry, it's
2602, let me, let me go next door and get them. I set the phone down, stand there for a couple
minutes, you know, like, $2,600. It's like, oh, wow, you guys are really here, you know, it's like,
yeah, you know, people keep calling us and people, people keep calling the guys next door, I don't know,
I guess they got the number wrong in the magazine or something, but, you know, the correct number is,
and then I gave him the number of the pay phone next to me. Well, he's like, oh, okay, sorry about that,
so, you know, hang up. Five minutes later, sure enough, you know, the other pay
phone rings. He's like, oh, and I forgot to ask you. Like, oh, you got the right number now, so.
So, anybody, go ahead. Yeah, guys want to meet more often you meet more often you send
you to the BBS. One thing we do is to meet the first Friday and every third Saturday and a location
hopefully we'll try to do that. We don't particularly have like a structured meeting. Like, we have
the 2,600 meeting and then, like, we're pretty much separated by.
about a half an hour each way. But we all get together at one guy's house, Deadhead,
who's sitting in the front row down over here. And he's got a lot of land right on the, like,
right near Salt Lake. So we have trash fires, is what we call. And we go out there and we have basically
bonfires, and we talk about things like, why hasn't virtual reality taken off and stuff? And we just
dork out till three in the morning and then go home. I mean, and, you know, we do the same usual sort of
get-together stuff other people do. Like, someone do would be like,
hey, I'm having a barbecue this weekend. You know, y'all swing on by. And, you know, stuff like that that's pretty informal.
Our meeting, well, depends on what time you get there.
The official L.A. meeting is a union station, the train station, in the middle of downtown.
We're only there for two hours. We then move over to Philippe Stelly down the street,
and then over to the Denny's by the jail.
Exactly.
Well, here's like, here's my view on this. And now, if this is any of you out here, then I apologize for bashing on you, but I'm about to.
You come to DefCon and you sit in the hallway with your laptop.
you can be on the internet 362 other days out of the year.
Shut the damn laptop and go talk to somebody in real life.
